title: As of 30 November 2017, how many states, including D.C., will offer expanded Medicaid coverage to people meeting the Affordable Care Act's poverty requirements for expanded coverage?
preds: What happened on Septemeber 22nd? Plunged from 81% to 24% for Blue32, but now back up to 71% WotC with this one. Only 9 days left

"States offering expanded Medicaid coverage under the ACA or a future program will count as long as the coverage is offered to those meeting the poverty requirements of ACA's expansion program."
----------
hm... 'future program' eh? It depends on what the meaning of the word 'is' is.

In Maine this was approved in a referendum earlier this month.  I continue to assume that words mean something, so until residents can actually sign up, the coverage is not being offered within the definition of this Q.  I should probably look into this some more instead of just being grumpy about it.

https://ballotpedia.org/Maine_Question_2,_Medicaid_Expansion_Initiative_(2017) "On November 8, 2017, Gov. Paul LePage (R) . . . released a statement saying, " . . . . my administration will not implement Medicaid expansion until it has been fully funded by the Legislature at the levels DHHS [Department of Health and Human Services] has calculated, and I will not support increasing taxes on Maine families, raiding the rainy day fund or reducing services to our elderly or disabled.” The statement by LePage indicates that the implementation of Question 2 could conflict over how to fund the state's portion of the costs of Medicaid expansion and resulting delays in implementation. The Maine Office of Fiscal and Program Review estimated that the state's portion of the cost would be about $54.5 million per year, while LePage estimated the cost at closer to $100 million. Normally, initiatives go into effect 30 days after the official proclamation of election results. If the initiative requires spending beyond available state funds, however, and does not provide a funding mechanism, the effective date of the initiative can be delayed until 45 days into the following legislative session. Question 2 was written to give the Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) 90 days after its effective date to submit a plan to the federal government and 180 days to begin expanded coverage" 
~~~~~~~ 
COMMENT:  Given all of the above, and the closing date of Nov 30 on this question, if I was an Admin, I'd be leaning towards saying that ME doesn't satisfy the question because even in the best case scenario--no funding issues or objection from the Governor--it would be 30 days from 11/7 before it went into effect. (Darn!)
Going back to my original answer because Maine still has a process to go through that I didn't realize.

It passes, but do they meet the poverty requirements before the end of November withot certification of the election and implementation of legislation according to the question?  The GJO question -- "States offering expanded Medicaid coverage under the ACA or a future program will count as long as the coverage is offered to those meeting the poverty requirements of ACA's expansion program."  Seems to me that to be offered, there needs to be some implementation but who knows how the question will be resolved.

thx @JMR2017 for your information in the following thread.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/607252
I guess that means that even though Maine's voters overwhelmingly want the Medicaid expansion, they won't be eligible for the additional coverage under the Medicaid expansion as of the time this question resolves.

Headline: "Maine just resoundingly became the first state to expand Medicaid by ballot initiative"
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/11/07/maine-could-become-the-first-state-to-expand-medicaid-by-ballot-initiative/
"Maine voters [had] agreed to [expand Medicaid to the ACA version] by a nearly 20-percentage point margin by the time the measure was called by election watchers."
Switching totally to 33 for the next week because I have high hopes for Maine to approve Medicaid expansion next week.
I don't think anything is going to change in the next month or so.
Remaining states are Republican controlled & cannot do what their people want.

Very few legislatures are in session now, and nobody is likely to call a special to deal with this.  A few governors have some discretion in this matter under their respective state statutes, but pretty much everyone who is going to do anything has already done it.

For those wondering why the consensus is so varied, from @Anneinak (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/593574): This is from an Admin. Please upvote it so that it appears at the top of the feed tomorrow. Thanks @Anneinak. from @amory10
Thank you [@cmeinel] for passing this along. It turns out that on September 21, a superforecaster (Bruno Jahn) went on a popular German TV show and talked about GJ Open. We were flooded with traffic and forecasts, especially on The Monkey Cage challenge because it was linked to a tutorial for new users that walks them through forecasting on a question. In other words, I too thought it was bots…but it was just Germans! :) I will stay vigilant because the threat of bots is real and worth watching out for… please do let me know if you notice other suspicious activity. And thanks again for your email.
updating for the passage of time.
Pretty likely to stay where it is
Not too much of a change on my part, but an adjustment based on the current environment.

Seems like the last ditch effort to replace Obamacare will fail on 30 September.   This may inspire states that had not expanded Medicaid to take the extra money, though the 30 November window is short, so only slightly possible that 1 or 2 states would move by then.
It is to expensive for them.
If anything there will be states doing it simply to annoy DT and the GOP
All about money and america is going down very fast now i guess
The liberal states will screw over the poor yet again and blame the conservatives.

Shifting a bit toward 32 because I no longer think many states are going to expand coverage in the next two months. And I am still assuming the latest healthcare bill in the senate doesn't go through.
Most states don't understand health care and freak out with the idea of giving people more money especially red states
Best chances are Kansas or North Carolina opting to expanding. But there isn't enough time (from now till before 30th of Nov) to offer expansion.

Give the state of Health Care in the US. I don't think any state is crazy enough to drop what they have now. Secondly, I don't expect many will make anything happen given the short time frame, federal..."uncertainty" and what will happen to politicians approval numbers over the holiday season.

While states may consider Medicaid expansion in the coming weeks (http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/aug/12/mainers-to-consider-medicaid-expansion-this-fall/), none are likely to officially expand the program through legislation.  Additionally, no states are seriously discussing ending any Medicaid expansion programs. So, 32 is the number (31 states, plus DC, per the question).
Updating and modifying due to passage of time.

While there's some renewed efforts to explore this option in the remaining states given the failure of the ACA repeal (https://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/news/2017/08/01/georgia-chamber-refocusing-on-medicaid-expansion.html and http://www.chron.com/news/politics/article/After-Obamacare-repeal-fails-Democrats-press-for-11734234.php), I think the clock is running out on these states as far as this question is concerned.

There is a chance that NC will vote an expansion before november, even if the short timeframe make it unlikely. Local GOP has dropped a lawsuit to prevent de Democratic  governor to present a bill to expand medicare, i expect i will present one.  The timeframe make it highly unlikely that any state would drop their program by Nov 2017 even if a reapeal of the ACA was passed.

With the death of GOP's health care effort, states will likely look again at the benefit of Medicaid expansion. However, there's little time left for state legislatures to pass expansion efforts. It's increasingly looking as though the status quo will maintain through the end of this question.

It's been so long since ACA could have been implemented -- could only assume if a state wanted it, they'd have it by now. Could only see it going down to 31 if the Graham-Cassidy amendment is passed (if it can even be implemented in time) so realistically no chance

Legislative sessions are mostly over.  This doesn't seem likely to come up in a special session anywhere, but there might be states where the guv or a dept can do things by executive order or regulation change.   I suppose I should look into this.
It would help if I read the question more closely and included DC as a state in my count. Adjusted to account for my inability to read for comprehension.
The longer the health care fight plays out at the national level, the less likely it will be for states to expand Medicaid. Updating based on the challenges and time remaining.

Current plan is the Fed gov't will continue to support a large share of medicaid expansion so states considering the expansion have reason to do so. In Canada when the Federal government provided incentives for hospital building and health care expansion Provinces took the money because they wanted the contribution to Provincial coffers and not because there was a strong belief that the additional resources were necessary. No reason to think that American politicians will behave differently.

If BCRA passes, there will likely be no change. If it fails, a state legislature would have to push this through with either a veto-proof margin or a supportive governor. Not impossible, but not the most probable outcome at the moment.

Even Democratic-party-controlled State legislatures are unlikely to vote to expand Medicare for those meeting poverty requirements until Congress has taken final action on repealing/replacing the ACA and are confident that Courts are not going to challenge aspects of the new legislation, an outcome I believe is  unlikely to be fully resolved by  November 30.

State legislatures will wait to see how the Senate health care bill fares. Republican governors will likely veto any attempts, as happened a few months ago in Kansas. Maybe 1 additional state will pass, but its unlikely.
I do not think the number will change.
The Republicans are not going to see this health care bill come out no matter what. Schumer is gleefully waiting on this, and believes the Dems will have to be brought in.
Many states that are losing other options under the break up of the ACA might have no other choise other than expand, however the status quo is always likely.
This is the best estimate I can give. Searching for additional informaiton
Staying with prediction until healthcare bill vote.
Most states have decent people running them, but not all of them do,  some states have total psychopaths running them.

Status quo is a very powerful thing. With the current debate on health care, I don't see many states taking more or less initiative, though there is enough noise that it's possible one will be added (removing would probably be very unpopular).

With AHCA becoming more of a reality, it's less likely that states will opt to expand Medicaid under the potentially defunct ACA. Hedging more towards no change, as the Rep-controlled state legislatures will have little incentive to expand unless AHCA completely fails and health care is abandoned by the administration.

The tactic used by President Clinton to lower welfare numbers was to steer recipients to Social Security Disability instead of welfare.  At this time, 32 states and DC have decided to expand Medicaid for different reasons.  Some Republican controlled states will likely attempt to lower the numbers of Affordable Care Act recipients by steering them towards Medicaid by lowering the bar to qualify for Medicaid.  In my opinion, a couple more Republican states will decide to expand Medicaid.   https://www.healthcare.gov/glossary/federal-poverty-level-FPL/
https://www.healthcare.gov/medicaid-chip/medicaid-expansion-and-you/
http://www.kff.org/health-reform/slide/current-status-of-the-medicaid-expansion-decision/
I need to spend more time with this one before committing much more in any direction.
Most states are running Republican, governors and houses.
On reflection I do not think red states will change their views on Medicaid

Currently 32. With the current house healthcare bill in the senate not getting much support I don't see much happening on health care so raising 2nd category by 15% to 95% and lowering to 0 chance 3rd category. Still keeping 5% chance of one state expanding medicaid.
I think the status quo prevails, its usually the safest option, but there are enough noises from enough states trying to expand medicaid that I think one might sneak through.

This is not a new topic, and the politics of many states who have denied the expansion so far have no changed much. A few states could join but no more than a couple. Politicians rarely admit they were wrong so in states where even the Governor is hated for not doing it like Kansas , it is likely he will ride out the storm to losing his next election, but a few states are possible or even likely like North Carolina under a new dem gov.

We can expect to see the medicaid expansions remain the same as the GOP figures out what they want to do regarding health care. States will wait to see what the feds do and then act on health care measures. No state will repeal their medicaid expansion as taking away benefits doesn't sit well with the people. No state will expand their medicaid as federal uncertainties make doing so improbable.
Difficult politically to take away coverage. Legislation will bog down in Senate, probably.

Democrats, the Midwest, the West Coast and the Northeast already have Medicaid expansion programs. The only room for the growth of the program is through republican states in the southern region of the country. It is unlikely these same states will help prop up "Obamacare."
It seems hard to imagine anything related to the ACA current policy will change dramatically before the end of the year so I can't see many, if any, states changing policy this year.
I don't see any reason why their would be more state covering the expansion
Movement toward consensus. Expecting things to remain about the same.
The passage of AHCA by the House will provide sufficient cover for state legislatures and governors to kill any attempt to expand Medicaid in deep red states.

Everything about this is hard to guess out:  The political situations within several individual states, the fate of the TrumpCare project, the reaction in Congress to however that turns out, what Mr. Tangerine Man will do about it, and how individual state authorities will respond to all this.  Fasten your seat belts, it's going to be a bumpy ride.  [Full disclosure: I know that's not quite the correct quote, but in this case I don't care.]
I believe that nothing will change by Nov 30th on this front despite that Kansas has an initiative on its state ballot on November 7.
New healthcare law will still not be passed!
going to go with inertia and "anyone who could have, would have already" theory for now.
Republican Congress will probably find a way to send Medicaid to the states to spend. So it's a toss up between those who cut for political reasons and the chance that more will come on board.
Very unlikely R governors expand medicaid

Red states that have not expanded Medicaid will likely wait to see how the second attempt at health care reform by the administration shapes up. It's likely that, assuming health care can't get traction, 1-2 states will expand Medicaid before the deadline. A 3-state expansion is a little less likely at this time, as most red states have to contend with their Republican governors as well, some of whom have proven to be obstinate in working with their state legislatures.  Updated numbers to come once the health care battle, and the public's stomach for such fight, become clearer in the coming weeks.
